anchor.surface_text: and Whether in any event the appellant is entitled to refund of the money he had paid to the respondent company ? These are the four questions which have been agitated before us and we shall deal with such of them as are necessary for deciding this appeal.

holdings.text: Section 45 of the Insurance Act, 1938 applies to the policy as more than two years had expired from the date it was originally effected, despite its revival.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the revival of a lapsed policy constitutes a new contract or not for other purposes, it is clear from the wording of the operative part of s. 45 that the period of two years for the purpose of the section

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.45 operative part specifies period from date policy 'effected', meaning original date, not revival.

holdings.text: The three conditions of the proviso to s.45 are fulfilled: the statements suppressed material facts about serious ailments, the suppression was fraudulent, and the policy-holder knew they were false.

anchor.surface_text: The three conditions for the application of the second part of s. 45 are- (a) the statement must be on a material matter or must suppress facts which it was material to disclose (b) the suppression must be fraudulently made

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.45 proviso conditions to facts: ailments serious per evidence, deliberate false answers per s.17 Contract Act definition of fraud.

holdings.text: The ailments treated by Dr. Lakshmanan in 1943 were serious (anaemia, oedema, diarrhoea, cardiac asthma) and material to disclose, not trivial.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the learned trial Judge that the ailments for which Mahajan Deolal was treated by Dr. Lakshmanan in September-October, 1943, were trivial or casual ailments.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejection of trial judge's finding based on medical evidence credibility, doctor's fees, and symptoms severity.

holdings.text: Mahajan Deolal guilty of fraudulent suppression per s.17 Contract Act by deliberate false statements and active concealment of material facts.

anchor.surface_text: Fraud, according to s. 17 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 (IX of 1872), means and includes Inter alia any of the following acts committed by a party to a contract with intent to deceive another party

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17 defines fraud including false suggestion and concealment; applied to known false answers in proposal despite recent serious treatment.

holdings.text: The policy was vitiated by fraudulent suppression of material facts; first question answered against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are in agreement with the High Court in answering the first question against the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: s.45 applies, conditions met, High Court finding correct on evidence.

holdings.text: No waiver or estoppel; respondent company not estopped from contesting policy despite medical exams, as unaware of specific Dr. Lakshmanan treatment; Explanation to s.19 Contract Act inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, no question of waiver arises in the circumstances of this case, nor can the appellant take advantage of the Explanation to s. 19 of the Indian Contract Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Company lacked knowledge of concealed facts; statements basis of contract; concealment affected consent.

holdings.text: Unnecessary to decide whether appellant had insurable interest or if assignment was wagering contract under s.30 Contract Act, as fraud vitiates policy ab initio.

anchor.surface_text: Our finding on the first question makes it unnecessary for us to decide the second question, namely, whether the present appellant merely gambled on the life of Mahajan Deolal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fraud finding dispositive; assignee cannot claim better than fraudulent insured.

holdings.text: Appellant not entitled to refund of premiums; policy terms forfeit moneys on fraud; ss.64 and 65 Contract Act inapplicable where stipulation discharges on warranty breach; courts will not aid fraud.

anchor.surface_text: We are further in agreement with the High Court that in cases in which there is stipulation that by reason of a breach of warranty by one of the parties to the contract, the other party shall be discharged

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fraud bars recovery; specific stipulation and general principle against aiding fraud; ss.64/65 not apply to warranty breach discharges.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we have companye to the companyclusion that there in numbermerit in the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed as without merit; policy void due to fraudulent suppression; no entitlement to insurance amount or refund of premiums
